text: The world of algorithms is vast, but we can often split them into two distinct classes. The first class is those that are inherently useful. Think of your standard graph algorithms like DFS or BFS. These algorithms show up all over the place. They are efficient, and as a result, we like to understand them. The second class of algorithms we study are ones that are just purely beautiful. Think of the first time you saw the incredibly simple recursive implementation of Towers, Illinois. If you have a soul, you feel a sense of wonder, a sense of awe at the elegance of such an algorithm. It happens to not actually be that useful or efficient, as a matter of fact, but we still study it. Just as we like to read a work of fiction, it inspires us and motivates out of the box thinking. Today I want to talk about an algorithm that rightfully belongs in both classes and my personal favorite algorithm, the fast Fourier transform. The fast Fourier transform, or FFT, is, without exaggeration, one of the most important algorithms created in the last century. So much of the modern technology that we have today, such as wireless communication, GPS, and in fact, anything related to the vast field of signal processing, relies on the insights of the FFT. But it's also one of the most beautiful algorithms you ever see. And to be fair, to get a full appreciation of the applications of the FFT, you can't really avoid any of these ideas, but I want to do something a little different. At its core is an algorithm for calculating these types of matrix vector products efficiently. In fact, the only difference is that every single Omega in our original DfT matrix is now just replaced with Omega to the power of negative one, with a normalization factor of one over N. chapters.summary: We can often split algorithms into two distinct classes. The first class is those that are inherently useful. The second class is those that are just purely beautiful.
chapters.headline: We can often split algorithms into two distinct classes.

chapters.summary: The Fast Fourier Transform, or FFT, is one of the most important algorithms created in the last century. Much of the modern technology that we have today, such as wireless communication, GPS, relies on the insights of the FFT. chapters.summary: In this video, we show how to reverse evaluation using the FFT algorithm. The FFT is an algorithm for calculating matrix vector products. The idea of reversing evaluation feels like a significantly harder task.
